entry.title: Combined summary - BIP - Block size doubles at each reward halving with max block size of 32M
entry.summary: A proposal was made in November 2015 to gradually increase the maximum block size of Bitcoin. The proposal suggested increasing the block size to 2 MB at the next block subsidy halving, with subsequent increases at each halving until reaching a maximum block size of 32 MB. The proposal aimed to restore the default 32 MB block size originally implemented by Satoshi and provide a long-term solution without assuming future bandwidth and storage availability estimates. The maximum block size of 32 MB would allow for peak usage of approximately 100 transactions per second by 2031.The debate over block size continued for several years, with a compromise agreement known as the "SegWit2x" proposal being reached in 2017, including a soft fork to enable Segregated Witness (SegWit) and a subsequent hard fork to increase the block size to 2 MB. However, this proposal was eventually abandoned due to lack of consensus within the community. Other solutions have been proposed and implemented to address the scalability issue, such as the Lightning Network.In the Bitcoin community, there is ongoing debate about how decision-making should occur when it comes to hardforks. The Bitcoin Improvement Proposal 99 (BIP99) recommends a 95% miner upgrade confirmation with version bits for uncontroversial hardforks, similar to softforks. However, some argue that miners should not be left out of decision-making since they are part of the Bitcoin economy. Others believe that the more relevant factor in terms of economic involvement is acceptance of bitcoins as payment for real goods. Ultimately, what is relevant is the whole economy and who people want to spend their bitcoins with. There is also discussion around the difference between miners signaling intent and a 95% miner majority consensus rule for a hard-fork in Bitcoin. While the former is mostly informational only, the latter implies something that is not entirely accurate as it requires more than just a miner upgrade for basic safety. The economy is what matters in a hard-fork, not just the miners. Devs have even less of a choice in the matter. The best approach is a flag day that gets called off if there isn't clear consensus. The public vocal opinions of any part of the Bitcoin economy can sway the opinions of the other parts. Overall, the Bitcoin economy is a complex system where every part interacts with each other in ways more complex than imperative logic. The economic majority is essentially what matters in a hard fork, but everyone - miners, developers, public thought leaders, and businesses - is part of that economy. Although miners matter to some extent, they don't decide in the case of hardforks. Ultimately, the community needs to talk and upgrade together for a hard-fork to be successful, which includes users, ecosystem companies and miners.The author is revising a specification regarding block size, which aims to gradually restore the block size to its default of 32 MB as implemented by Satoshi. The revised spec proposes increasing the maximum block size to 2MB in the shorter term, with further increases at each subsidy halving until reaching a maximum block size of 32MB, allowing peak usage of approximately 100 transactions per second by the year 2031. The proposal also aims to provide a long-term solution that doesn't make enthusiastic assumptions about future bandwidth and storage availability estimates.In an email conversation on November 13, 2015, John Sacco suggested the inclusion of block signalling in a BIP. However, Luke Dashjr advised against it, stating that including block signalling gives people the false impression that miners have a say in hardforks.In a conversation on November 14, 2015, Angel Leon questioned whether the money supply was part of the economy. Luke Jr. replied that in the context of economic majority deciding hardforks, the money supply was not considered part of the economy. However, the more relevant factor in terms of economic involvement is the acceptance of bitcoins as payment for real goods.In an email conversation, Jorge Timón and Shuning Hong discussed the time threshold for upgrading a Bitcoin Improvement Proposal (BIP) and what would happen if miners did not upgrade. The majority of miners not upgrading could cause a hardfork to timeout, indicating that either the minimum activation threshold was too short or the hardfork was actually controversial. If some still wanted to deploy it as a schism hardfork, BIP99 recommends using only a mediantime threshold without versionbits nor miner upgrade confirmation. It would be nice to have an equivalent mechanism to wait for the rest of the users, but unfortunately, there's none.The proposal aims to gradually restore block size to the default 32MB setting originally implemented by Satoshi and provide a long-term solution that doesn't make enthusiastic assumptions about future bandwidth and storage availability estimates.
